abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Water Supply Sector
            Project is rated as satisfactory, sustainability as likely,
            institutional development impact as modest, Bank performance
            as satisfactory, and Borrower performance as satisfactory.
            During the early years of the project, Burundi experienced
            turmoil, with the death of two Presidents of the Republic,
            one during an attempted coup in 1993 and the other in Rwanda
            in in 1994. Country circumstances made it impossible for the
            project actors to carry out their activities. Cofinanciers
            also suspended their participation in 1996. The most
            important lesson learned from the difficult history of the
            project is that even in conflict situations, it is possible
            to restructure projects and to achieve high impact by
            concentrating on the most basic level of services and using
            adapted and low-cost solutions. Another related lesson is
            that in crisis situations, a bottom-up approach is more
            likely to succeed. Delegating implementation
            responsibilities to dedicated nongovernemtnal organizations
            also may restore a degree of trust that governmental bodies
            are unable to inspire. Moreover, building on the
            achievements of a "highly satisfactory" project
            does not warrant the success of a follow-up operation and
            does not automatically warrant that the quality at entry
            will be satisfactory. The design and implementation of cost
            recovery policies for rural water services should bring
            users in the picture through willingness-to-pay studies and
            social assessments.

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objectives of the project are
            to:  (a) improve the quality and quantity of potable water
            provided to the rural population; (b) increase the local
            population's sense of responsibility for maintaining
            its water supply facilities; (c) help the government develop
            and implement appropriate institutional and financial
            arrangements in the water supply sector; (d) extend the
            pricing policy initiated under the rural water supply
            project to the entire country; (e) coordinate donor activity
            in the rural water supply sector; and (f) help the
            government prepare and monitor a public expenditure program
            for the sector.  The project includes the following
            components:  (a) construction of rural water supply systems
            in 9 provinces (Kayanza, Ngozi, Karuzi, Muyinga, Gitega,
            Muramvya, Cibitoke, Bubanza,, and Makamba); (b) development
            and protection of about 3,000 springs; and (c) capacity
            building in the Department of Rural Water Resources and
            Electrification through the provision of expertise,
            equipment and training; in the communes and the communal
            water utilities through the provision of training and
            sensitization of population; and in the National Water and
            Electricity Authority through the provision of studies.
